messageBody:
----- Original Message -----
From: "Jeff Tulley" <j_tulley@...>


>
> How do you do TDD with a separate, independent tester?
> That goes against what TDD is, unless the tester is
> pair programming with the developer.

I see no reason why you cannot do both TDD and have a separate independent
unit tester. At worst you would have some duplication of effort and at best
you would have someone who would catch test cases the developer didn't. Same
could be said of pair programming, and that seems to work for some people.

I don't see any conflict either, whether it is done as part of a pair
programming effort or as a totally independent effort. Where do you see the
conflict?

Now, if you also have another person writing unit tests at the same time the
code is being developed, then you get the benefit of a second pair of
independent and fresh unbiased eyes. After all, we have code walkthroughs
and peer reviews right? If every developer could see the errors in their
code and develop tests to exclude them, then what is the purpose of those
practices? Such practices are just another form of testing.

>
> I do sometimes worry though that my testcode doesn't test the boundary
cases too well since it is
> not my dedicated job to make the code break. But, with TDD my code is
90-100% tested whereas
> therwise it would be 10% (if that). That is such a marked improvement
that I think it is well worth it,
> even without independent testing.

I am not arguing against TDD, or arguing that independent unit testing
would/should replace TDD - far from it. I am saying that independent unit
testing has its own value and serves as another very important early filter
for bugs in code and designs. Again, the earlier you find a bug, the better,
and it is well worth the extra effort - unless the effort doesn't find bugs,
which I seriously doubt.

FWIW,
Lauren
